content: Chromium(III) nitrate nonahydrate (Cr(NO3)3·9H2O, >99.0%, from Tianjin), 1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, ≥99.0%, Acros Organic), and hydrofluoric acid (HF, 48%, from Merck) were used as received from vendors without further purification. The chromium−terephthalate MIL-101 was synthesized at 493 K for 60 min under microwave irradiation at 300 W. The molar composition of the reactant mixture was Cr(NO3)3·9H2O:H2BDC:HF:H2O 1:1:1:278. The reactant mixture was loaded into a Teflon autoclave, sealed, and placed in a microwave oven (Mars-5, CEM). The autoclave was heated to 493 K in 15 min and kept at this temperature for 60 min. After the reaction time, the reactor was cooled to room temperature. A fine green colored powder was obtained as the major product. To obtain high porosity, the as-synthesized MIL-101 was purified by using the reported method. Contents were completely transferred into a conical flask, and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, >99%, from Mallinckrodt) was added incrementally with continuous shaking to dissolve the H2BDC. By repeating washing with DMF and centrifugation, most of the terephthalic acid was removed from MIL-101. However, a significant amount of free H2BDC within the pores of MIL-101 was still found. To remove this extra H2BDC from the pores, an additional ethanol (>99.7, from Tianjin Fuyu) rinse was performed. About 400 mg of MIL-101 powder and 30 mL of ethanol were placed in an autoclave at 393 K for 20 h. After cooling, the resulting product was centrifuged and washed with ethanol. Finally, the product was dried at 423 K overnight.
clean_text:
Experimental Sections

Synthesis of MIL-101

Chromium(III) nitrate nonahydrate (Cr(NO3)3⋅9H2O, >99.0%, from Tianjin), 1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid (H2BDC, ≥99.0%, Acros Organic), and hydrofluoric acid (HF, 48%, from Merck) were used as received from vendors without further purification. The chromium-terephthalate MIL-101 was synthesized at 493 K for 60 min under microwave irradiation at 300 W. The molar composition of the reactant mixture was Cr(NO3)3⋅9H2O:H2BDC:HF:H2O 1:1:1:278. The reactant mixture was loaded into a Teflon autoclave, sealed, and placed in a microwave oven (Mars-5, CEM). The autoclave was heated to 493 K in 15 min and kept at this temperature for 60 min. After the reaction time, the reactor was cooled to room temperature. A fine green colored powder was obtained as the major product. To obtain high porosity, the as-synthesized MIL-101 was purified by using the reported method. Contents were completely transferred into a conical flask, and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, >99%, from Mallinckrodt) was added incrementally with continuous shaking to dissolve the H2BDC. By repeating washing with DMF and centrifugation, most of the terephthalic acid was removed from MIL-101. However, a significant amount of free H2BDC within the pores of MIL-101 was still found. To remove this extra H2BDC from the pores, an additional ethanol (>99.7, from Tianjin Fuyu) rinse was performed. About 400 mg of MIL-101 powder and 30 mL of ethanol were placed in an autoclave at 393 K for 20 h. After cooling, the resulting product was centrifuged and washed with ethanol. Finally, the product was dried at 423 K overnight.
